src:
'IMPEACHMENT'
El embajador de Trump en la UE revisa su testimonio y señala al presidente
Sondland dice que se condicionó la ayuda a Ucrania a investigaciones de interés político para TrumpLos demócratas anuncian que las vistas públicas en el Congreso comenzarán el próximo miércoles
06 Nov 2019, 00:13 by Idoya Noain
La ya frágil defensa de Donald Trump ante la investigación para un 'impeachment' abierta por los demócratas en el Congreso sigue recibiendo golpes. Uno contundente ha llegado de su embajador ante la Unión Europea, Gordon Sondland, que ha admitido 391 millones de dólares de ayuda militar a Ucrania se retuvieron como forma de presionar a Kiev para que realizara investigaciones que iban en interés político personal de Trump.
El varapalo es significativo para Trump al llegar de Sondland, un hotelero y gran donante al que no puede denostar como opositor a su presidencia, como suele hacer con quienes hacen declaraciones que le perjudican. El nuevo diplomático compareció el 17 de octubre ante el Congreso y, en más de 10 horas de testimonio a puerta cerrada, negó que hubiera habido quid pro quo y aseguró que creyó a Trump cuando le dijo que no lo había. Tras declaraciones de otros testigos y una vez se han empezado a hacer públicas las transcripciones de esas comparecencias, no obstante, Sondland ha enmendado su declaración inicial diciendo que esos otros testimonios le han “refrescado la memoria”.
Quid pro quo
En una carta de cuatro páginas enviada el lunes al Congreso que se hizo pública el martes, Sondland reconoce que el 1 de septiembre mantuvo en Varsovia una conversación con Andréi Yermak, asesor del presidente ucranio Volodímir Zelenski, en la que le explicó que la ayuda posiblemente no se reanudaría hasta que Ucrania hiciera una declaración pública de que iba a investigar la "corrupción". Otro material desclasificado el martes, en concreto mensajes de texto de Kurt Volker, que fue enviado especial de Trump para Ucrania y dimitió tras estallar el escándalo, clarifica que Washington exigía que el propio Zelenski hiciera una declaración anunciando una investigación tanto de Burisma, la empresa energética en la que trabajó el hijo del exvicepresidente y aspirante presidencial demócrata Joe Biden, como de la supuesta injerencia de Ucrania en las elecciones de EEUU de 2016 (una teoría conspiratoria desacreditada).
La Casa Blanca reaccionó con un comunicado en el que se llegaba a asegurar que “hay incluso menos pruebas de lo que se pensaba” para el 'impeachment', que se tacha de “farsa”. El proceso, no obstante, sigue adelante con fuerza. Aunque el bloqueo de la Casa Blanca continúa y el jefe de gabinete en funciones, Mick Mulvaney, ya ha anunciado que no acudirá a testificar el viernes, las primeras vistas públicas comenzarán el próximo miércoles.

text:
'IMPEACHMENT'
Trump's ambassador to the EU reviews his testimony and points to the president
Sondland says aid to Ukraine was conditioned on investigations of political interest to Trump Democrats announce that public hearings in Congress will begin next Wednesday
06 Nov 2019, 00:13 by Idoya Noain
The already fragile defense of Donald Trump before the investigation for an impeachment opened by the Democrats in the Congress continues receiving blows. A blunt one has arrived from his ambassador to the European Union, Gordon Sondland, who has admitted 391 million dollars of military aid to Ukraine withheld as a way of pressuring Kiev to conduct investigations that were in Trump's personal political interest.
The varapalo is significant for Trump when he arrives from Sondland, a hotelier and a great donor who cannot be insulted as an opponent of his presidency, as he usually does with those who make statements that harm him. The new diplomat appeared before Congress on October 17 and, in more than 10 hours of testimony behind closed doors, denied that there had been quid pro quo and said he believed Trump when he told him there was none. Following statements by other witnesses and once the transcripts of those appearances have begun to be made public, however, Sondland has amended his initial statement saying that those other testimonies have "refreshed his memory."
Quid pro quo
In a four-page letter sent to Congress on Monday that was made public on Tuesday, Sondland acknowledges that on September 1 he had a conversation in Warsaw with Andrei Yermak, an advisor to Ukrainian President Volodimir Zelenski, in which he explained that he could possibly help her It would not resume until Ukraine made a public statement that it would investigate "corruption." Another declassified material on Tuesday, specifically text messages from Kurt Volker, who was Trump's special envoy for Ukraine and resigned after the scandal broke out, clarifies that Washington demanded that Zelenski himself make a statement announcing an investigation of both Burisma, the company energy in which the son of former Vice President and Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden worked, as of the alleged interference of Ukraine in the 2016 US elections (a discredited conspiracy theory).
The White House reacted with a statement saying that “there is even less evidence than previously thought & rdquor; for the 'impeachment', which is labeled as “farce & rdquor ;. The process, however, continues strongly. Although the White House blockade continues and the acting chief of staff, Mick Mulvaney, has already announced that he will not come to testify on Friday, the first public hearings will begin next Wednesday.
